newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan MOF says keeping close watch over oil prices.
newsitem.headline: Japan MOF says keeping close watch over oil prices.

text.p: Japan's Ministry of Finance (MOF) is keeping a close watch over international crude oil price movements and their impact on the country's trade surplus, a ministry official told a news briefing on Wednesday.
"Crude oil made up 8.9 percent of overall imports last year. It is a big chunk and we are keeping very careful watch over the global crude oil trade and price movements," the official said.
Official trade figures announced earlier showed that Japan's crude oil imports for August rose 53.8 percent from a year earlier, mainly due to an increase in global prices.
He reiterated the ministry's view that the trade surplus was still on a declining trend, as growth in imports continued to exceed that of exports.
But he also added that the trend may change depending on foreign exchange rates, crude oil prices and global economic conditions.
Overall car exports in August grew 18.3 percent year-on-year, mostly due to slow growth last year, he said.
Although growth in car exports to the United States was capped as Japanese makers switched to local production, good demand in Europe and Asia continued to support car exports.
Imports of aircraft, which grew 372.2 percent in August from a year ago, contributed to overall growth in imports that month, the official said.
Japan bought three planes, worth more than 10 billion yen each, from the United States, he said. Imports of aircraft from the United States in August grew 437.0 percent from a year ago.
